{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3561831,"name":"","username":"dan_frc","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dan_frc/{size}/257062_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T16:13:46.168Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôve been watching many games and I can see how snappy their subsystems are, yet they still get to their set point dead accurate, I know this involves profiling, but is that really all it is?

Their elevator is snappy, their arms are snappy basically everything they have is snappy and fast

Our robot this season used basic PID without essential things such as feed forward, and we‚Äôre looking to improve the speed of it all in the off season. What should I look at when it comes to getting that fast and snappy movement?

And some other things that I want to clear up:

How much does profiling help to achieve this snappy movement? Should I be using Motion Magic for this? Or a profiledPID controller + feed forward

How much of a difference does it make with feed forward compared to not using it?

Our subsystems are 2 stage elevator and an pivoting arm.

FYI we use CIMs and VictorSPXs and REV through bore encoders

Our elevator is fairly fast and accurate this year. It does not run any form of PID - it is a simple variant of a trapezoidal profile where it ramps up to a max speed over a set time (something like 0.1s), and cruises at that max speed until the error * gain curve intersects with the max speed. The speed then reduces following the error * gain curve down.

Here‚Äôs a video of the elevator in motion:

drive.google.com

20250218_185617.mp4

Google Drive file.

And this is a graph of our motion:
The purple line is error*gain, the yellow line command to the motor (-100 to 100%), and the blue line is position feedback. Note that this was before feedforward was added so there‚Äôs some bouncing at the position.

Screenshot_20250319_123445_Slack1080√ó1162 92.4 KB

Note how the yellow ramps up to 100%, cruises at 100%, then ‚Äúrides down‚Äù with the purple error*gain

Brandon_L:

It does not run any form of PID
‚Ä¶
The purple line is error*gain

To prevent any confusion here: This is just a PID with ki=0 and kd=0, forming a P controller. This subset of PID control happens to be extremely easy to implement without a library, but all normal PID discussion applies.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-19T18:47:58.955Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":91,"readers_count":90,"score":33.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":496217,"topic_slug":"snappy-and-fast-subsystem-movement","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/snappy-and-fast-subsystem-movement/496217/4","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3562145,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T18:58:09.107Z","cooked":"
dan_frc:

How much does profiling help to achieve this snappy movement? Should I be using Motion Magic for this? Or a profiledPID controller + feed forward

It accounts for a lot. Using a motion profile makes most tuning issues trivial, and is absolutely worth using, even if you have poor tuning involved. Even with bad tunings, you‚Äôll end up with Good Enough control almost immediately, and can improve from there for speed, precision, and stability. Motion Magic in particular is lauded as being ‚Äúactually magic‚Äù for how well it generates this motion.

The key insight here is that a PID controller tends to handle poorly when you have large setpoint changes: EG, going from 0 inches to 40 inches. These changes generates a large output spike, which grinds gears and stresses your robot and makes things move very quickly. While you can tune your I and D terms to combat this, unless you‚Äôre very good at it, it‚Äôs a very iterative, slow, process that‚Äôs easy to get wrong and cause really nasty motions.
Using a motion profile makes these setpoint changes much smaller, meaning your PID control never generates huge spikes in output to begin with, and the robot behaves pretty well even with poor PID and feedforward tunings. From here you mostly have to get your basic FeedForwards (especially kg), and you‚Äôll have a robot that can be easily misconstrued as well tuned.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-19T19:00:43.743Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":72,"readers_count":71,"score":14.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":496217,"topic_slug":"snappy-and-fast-subsystem-movement","display_username":"Dan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":44763,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2811 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/snappy-and-fast-subsystem-movement/496217/5","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3562151,"name":"Clay","username":"63hz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/63hz/{size}/262762_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T18:59:31.733Z","cooked":"

Something important to consider when building a mechanism that you hope to make fast and snappy (which functionally translates to high acceleration, high velocity, high positional accuracy) is a mechanical system that is very light, but is still very rigid and tightly actuated mechanically. By that I mean:

Assuming all else is constant (same motor,same gear reduction mostly):

  1. Light: Lighter systems can be accelerated and decelerated more quickly/with less torque.
  2. Rigid: A rigid system will not flex noticeably when subjected to forces due to acceleration (bending beams where rigging/ropes/belts are attached to it). It is build strong enough to withstand the high forces involved in being accelerated or decelerated very quickly. Assuming you‚Äôre using very strong motors, it‚Äôs totally possible that you could set your acceleration and velocities high enough that your mechanism could destroy itself while trying to accelerate faster than the structure can handle. F=MA.
  3. A rigid system has tight (but not too tight) belts/ropes/rigging such that there is not slack that needs to be taken up before the system actually starts moving. When it comes to a stop the system doesn‚Äôt bounce or overshoot its setpoint because of slop/slack in the rigging/belts/ropes.

I‚Äôm sure there are other considerations, but these are lessons learned on our team from this year so I‚Äôm speaking from recent experience.

Tuning is great, and can make a properly built mechanism into a screaming fast machine, but if the system is not robust enough for such speeds and accelerations, no amount of tuning is going to fix that.

Good luck!
